title: At close of business on 10 June 2020, will the upper limit of the Federal Reserve's target range for the federal funds rate be lower, the same, or higher than it was at close of business on 29 April 2020?
preds: I think it is most likely the same especially since today is the 9th of June I’m just not comfortable with saying 100%
This won't be moving in the next few hours.
Small probability they'll lower rates in case something else bad happens.
Changing things up a  bit to reflect current situation
Negative interest rate seem unlikely given the relative smoothness of the economic reopening
Trump pushing for below Zero but Powell said he will not do that.

There is some talk of negative interest rates [1], but that doesn't seem to be in consideration for the near term. The NYT notes that a new philosophy may be in at the Fed, to keep interest rates low well the job market recovers [2]. A meeting seems unlikely in the next few days to push rates lower, but removing the increase completely and keeping a small percentage on a decrease. [1] https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/28/standard-chartered-if-fed-opts-for-negative-rates-it-will-be-a-hail-mary.html
[2] https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/22/business/economy/fed-interest-rates-coronavirus.html
Powell says never lower than Zero
Could see a narrowing of the band without going negative.  Increase the chance this happening, also some non-zero chance of negative rates in the US despite Fed arguing against this.

In the last meeting on 15 March 2020, the FOMC set the interest rate target at 0.0 - 0.25%. This is done to improve the economy, increase the money supply and in response to the Pandemic crisis.  Although the Fed is against the negative rates, voices are growing to emulate European experience to reduce to negative rates.  With one of the worst recession in the last 100 years, there are chances that the rate may dive into the negative territory. Hence, my forecast is it may remain at the same level, go down by a quarter point or enter into negative territory.

Current target rate as of mid-March is 0.00–0.25% [1], which was maintained in the April meeting [2]. With unemployment as low as it is, it seems unlikely they will raise the upper limit. This is the lowest range they have had, so it seems unlikely they will drop it lower [3]. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_funds_rate
[2] https://www.marketwatch.com/story/read-the-federal-reserves-april-statement-2020-04-29
[3] https://www.thebalance.com/fed-funds-rate-history-highs-lows-3306135

11MAY2020 rate range is set at zero to .25, question is in regards to the upper limit only. https://www.bondbuyer.com/news/as-coronavirus-hits-economy-fomc-keeps-rates-steady-eyes-new-data
https://www.bankrate.com/rates/interest-rates/federal-funds-rate.aspx
slight change due to passage of time
No need to take interest rate action. Won’t go negative even as economy weakens.
maintaining current forecast. Updating for passage of time.

It really depends on when we hit the apex of the coronavirus.  The economy is not slowing due to lack of demand but lack of supply, which is extremely rare.  This probably has not happened since the Spanish flu of 1918.   Yet, once we are past the downside all the ingredients should be there for a rapid recovery.  Interest rates are already almost at zero, but Congress and the president will no doubt sign another stimulus plan. The only thing that could throw all this into further chaos is if the stimulus hits as the economy is shirking because people will not go back to work due to coronavirus fears.  This could create hyperinflation and similar increases in interest rates.  I am betting the apex will occur around the end of April.  Therefore, the workforce will start to go back to work in about May so any inflation caused by excess demand would collide with a workforce now willing to fill jobs in empty factories and service businesses.  This of course would lead to a growing economy with very low inflation and interest rates.

The FED has introduced all manner of lending vehicles, including one backstopped by Treasury.  They will continue to work with these QE-type policies before considering dropping the Fed funds rate below zero, which is what would come next.

Most likely, any change in rates will happen by 29 April and then no change through the June meeting.  But some chance that the epidemic continues/worsens and Fed makes further adjustment lower.  Also a slight chance that recovery is swift and vigorous and fiscal stimulus prompts inflation causing Fed to partially reverse interest cuts.

Given today's actions where they didn't opt for a push lower than the zero bound, but included new policy's that they have never conducted, I am revising my "same" option higher, at the expense of lower.
I'm not assuming that down is 0%. Other central banks have shown that negative targets are a thing.

It is zero now. Trump has pushed them to go below Zero but Powell does not want to do that. Note: Trump Org would gain if it did go below zero. Controversial is Trump says he can demote or remove Powell. https://www.marketwatch.com/story/trump-says-he-has-the-right-to-dismiss-or-demote-fed-chairman-powell-2020-03-14
It will probably be the same but stay tuned.

On March 15th the Fed cut the fed funds range by 100bps to 0-0.25% in light of the likely impact of the coronavirus on the US economy. By some estimates the US might be facing the worst quarter of economic growth since records began.  In answering this question there are nine different possible paths of interest rates, looking at the movement from now until 29th April, and then the movement from the 29th April until the 10th June: Lower Lower, Lower Same, Lower Higher, Same Lower etc. Given the environment that we are in, with economic activity falling and a recent sharp fall in the oil price, I think it is possible to virtually eliminate any options which include "Higher" in either period, leaving the options LL, LS, SL, SS.
Given the lower and upper bound are 0-0.25% any move lower would encompass the lower bound breaching the zero bound (assuming that we maintain a 25bps difference between the 2 rates). I think this is unlikely because:
•	The previous and first time rates were at this record low level was during the financial crisis, when the US economy was again facing very significant challenges, the Fed still did not decide to push rates lower than 0% (as close as we can come to a base rate)
•	The experience of Europe and Japan with negative interest rates since then, is likely to further dissuade the Fed from pushing rates lower
There is a possibility that the upper bound is lowered while maintaining the lower bound at 0%, although I can’t find a historical precedent for this (happy to be shown otherwise?). In the case that the Fed did either breach the 0% level or reduced the spread between the upper and lower bound, it is still possible that they do this before the forecasting dates and then keep the rates the same over the forecasting period i.e. a Lower Same option. On the flip side it is possible if the extent to the economic damage is revealed to be worse than previously thought, the Fed may keep rates the same until the forecasting period, before deciding to lower again with more data evident. Taking this all of this into account, I believe same should be heavily weighted taking into account the Fed’s actions following 2008, lower as a low probability, and higher as a very outside chance.  https://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/files/monetary20200315a1.pdf
https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/20/goldman-sees-an-unprecedented-stop-of-economic-activity-with-2nd-quarter-gdp-contracting-by-24percent.html
Economic effects of pandemic will still be felt and Fed will still be propping up the economy. It is pointless, but they will do it anyway.
Powell seems to be strongly signalling against the Fed going into negative interest rate territory.
maintaining forecast. updating due to passage of time.

Oops adjusted wrong question.  This is June. Still a question of economic data showing a recovery by june 10. I will hedge a bit but really do not believe fed wil raise rates until after june gdp report.
Mkved back to 100 percent same. They are at 0 and the statement was very strong that it will stay there jntil a recovery. Even anticipating a v shaped recovery April 29 is too soon for the take-off.
Unlikely to cut below zero and recovery won't be fast enough to hike in H1

Ok this may sound strange.  I believe covid 19 infection rates by month May are near zero, panic over. The economy is awash in credit with fed rate at 0 and fed supporting the money markets with trillion dollar buys, and the administartion spendinf fema money and special budgeth provisions for those laid off.   Fed is going to quote the increase in economic acrivity as justifiction for a 25 basis point increase.  Its possible the eclnomic activity doesnt get going till june and i am wrong on the timing. That is why i am at 50/50.

I did not realize that "same" was a common outcome and it was not a continuous variable. I do think it's possible it gets raised, e.g. if the virus comes back or something weird happens with the economy.

Assuming the Fed will be out of ammo by May. Other measures will be used by others to prop up the economy.
Helicopter money could be a welcome way to get people out of their houses.
Adjusting based on consensus opinion that the Fed will go to zero over the next two meetings to combat the coronavirus impacts

By time 29th April rolls around I think we be at the tail end of the coronavirus peak. Possible more cuts before then. But after I think Fed will go into a holding pattern for a few months with a view to normalising rates asap as economy picks back up. Central Banks globally are emphasising that cuts due to coronavirus are temporary.
Likely that "lower" on 10 June will mean negative rates, something the US Fed is definitely not keen on.
What clowns if they lower it again so soon. Last time was such an epic fail, they should have learned. The only way to prop up the all-important stock market any longer is by monetising the stocks.

Given what the market is currently pricing in (50-75bps cut at the March meeting AFTER the 50 bps infra-meeting cut) I’m increasing the likelihood of them holding in June. Based on the market-implied probability, my estimate is 65% chance they hold in June.  Recent language from the Fed (especially on Friday), though, suggests that they could be saving ammo til later in the year. The question is are they saving that ammo to abate the effects of the Coronavirus or are they looking passed the virus to other potential crises? The market is implying the ZLB in Apr (33%) and June (39%). Going there in April seems unlikely so I’m adjusting my probability to 60-40.

v close call at the moment. Fed is meeting again on March 18th and then again 28th-29th April. So we're looking at what happens past the 29th, which is obviously related to their next two decision points (if they've gone to zero by the 29th, for instance, then rates can't really go anywhere). The 18th isn't far away and the strong labour market data released today may give the Fed confidence to hold their fire for another month, given the emergency rate cut that's already happened. Should they not act on the 18th, then it seems very likely they will in April, and probably again shortly thereafter. If they act on the 18th and again in April, the picture is much less clear. Historically the Fed has been too slow to react to crises but Powell is at least signalling a strong desire to get ahead of the curve.

Its going to be the same because the FED does not drop rates one month and then raise them the next.  An emergency cut in March is not going to be followed with a raise 3 months later.  If the 10 yr interst rate goes back to 150 then yeah the FED will raise.  I am excluding lower because I believe the covid 19 is over hyped and will be yesterdays news by May.
Mr. Market may still be asking for help in April. My guess is they cut until there is no more to cut.
Market pricing implies zero probability of hikes. Cuts will depend on actions taken at March meeting at which the market is expecting another 50bps cut.

Based on yesterday's cut. The date range makes it tough to predict though, since we have to consider both what happens before April 29 and what happens from April 29 to June 10. It's possible that Fed will cut before April 29 and then stay put. Or not cut before April 29 and then cut.

In light of the Fed's action today, I wanted to work through this question based on what the market is pricing in based on the probabilities implied by Fed Funds futures (https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html). Fed Funds futures view:
- Market is suggesting a roughly 50-50 chance of the Fed cutting again in April
- Looking at June the probabilities are as follows: 16% for 50-75, 49% for 75-100, and 35% for 100-125
- This would mean that IF the Fed holds at 100-125 in April, there is a 65% chance they cut in June
- IF the Fed cuts to 75-100 in April, there is a 75% chance they will hold in June (49/(49+16))
- Therefore, the probability that rates are lower (sum of the cuts) is 44% and 56% for hold  This is roughly in line with my prior forecast of 57% Same and 43% Lower so I will hold and continue to monitor. We have a jobs report on Friday (3/6) and an inflation report next Wednesday (3/11).
Latest rate cut not necessarily indicative of a similar move in April
The has preemptively shot all its powder, there is nothing left in the bazooka.
Losing wiggle room with the emergency cut.  The FED might feel pressure to cut again if things don't pick up
Raising "lower" percentage due to Powell's announcement on 2/28; rates may not change between April and June even if they're lowered before April, but markets took quite a hit this week
Toss up, it will be done here if not in April. Could be both.
Coronavirus impact could push to lower rates, although this is a production impact, not a financial impact.
If not April then perhaps June to lower rates to be shown as "doing something" to help business stay afloat should the coronavirus impact productivity in the US as it has in China, Korea and Japan.

The US economy is currently relatively strong, therefore the fed is likely to increase rates over the next few months unless the global economy has a significant enough downturn to impact the US. Lower represents significant impact of Coronavirus over next 4/5 months, same represents financial uncertainty, higher represents a decline in the virus and return to stability in financial markets.

Forecasts seem to expect the rate to hold for a full 12 months based on predictable factors, unfortunately, all predictable factors are gone. CoronaVirus is destroying the financial sector which should result in the Feds holding or even lowering the interest rates, but our leadership is financially insane. Lowering would reduce or stabilize the value of US debt that Chins holds by reducing the return on the US dollar and lowering demand for cash. This particular admin is more likely to raise the upper limit just to increase unfulfilled demand for cash and in turn, increase the value of the US dollar against the Yuan and inadvertently increase the value of US debt  China holds. Although in the end, this would reduce the probability of runaway inflation during market rebound.

While the US economy is not affected by the coronavirus outbreak in the short term, it could affect the US and the world's economy as outbreaks outside China appear to likely.  The Fed might decide to lower the rate to counter a potential slowdown or recession.

More in more I think this question needs to be rephrased as “will the Fed cut again in June after it cuts in April?”  I think it is almost certain (90%) that the fed funds rate will be lower in June than it is today (150-175bps). If the Fed cuts once in April, though, the case for a second cut only strengthens if the situation further deteriorates. By that time the US and most of the major economies are in the summer. Warmer weather and humidity are less optimal for transmission than cold and dry. If that scenario plays out then I see the Fed holding flat.  Obvious downside risks are a second insurance cut, or the fed does not cut in April.
I don't see any chance of rates go higher as China is recovering from Corona-virus and Europe and other countries are getting hit by the virus.

Dollar strength, coronavirus fears, weakening manufacturing data, and low inflation. The only bright spot in the US and global growth outlook is the consumer. If travel grinds to a halt, however, even this is in risk.  At the same time, the rate of new infections is slowing according to the WHO, unemployment is low, housing is strong, and the Fed has some room to act. Also, fed officials are pretty adamant that cuts will not be needed (https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/20/clarida-on-squawk-.html and https://www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/speech/clarida20200221a.htm) This is reminds me a lot of the position we were in last year - Fed says they are data-dependent and willing to buck “conventional” monetary rules (Phillips curve) to support the expansion. I think the next few months will tell a lot. A slowing coronavirus will likely keep the Fed on hold. There is also the risk that my March and (more so) April forecast are wrong and that the fed will cut before June and then hold steady.
I believe they will be holding position.

Every time I see another alert on oil prices, it is about the growing excess inventories.  Oil prices are the most important predictors of the so-called misery index.  Therefore, read GDP growth might remain high without inflation.
Fed does not historically cut rates during an election year. Coronavirus impact has to be taken into account though.
Election rates don't rise, GM makes for a good canary and the corona virus has yet to peak, the economic pressure once the next rounds of trade blockages take force will force industry to the wall.
Trumps not letting them raise rates in an election year.   We will do anything to kickstart any sign of a sputtering economy,

Conclusion: Despite the Coronavirus affecting supply chains and global economic health, the American markets still seem relatively buoyant (though that may change between now and June).  On that facet alone it seems unlikely that rates would change, though Trump has been pressuring the Fed to lower them; overall, a downturn/pessimistic forecast for the economy is more likely than an optimistic one, so rates are likely to either lower or stay the same.  At the moment it seems more probable that they will stay the same, but if there is an economic downturn that leads to increased pressure from Trump and the markets, this forecast will be revised.
Election year - Trump will pressure the Fed to keep rates low.

Trump has an agenda for the Fed post re-election and is applying constantly applying pressure on Powell to lower rates. With Coronavirus affecting Chinese supply chains, it's likely there will be a slow down making Fed lowering rates likely, and with the ECB looking to loosen policy as well while DJT has the EU in line for a trade war next, I see downside pressure prevailing.

There are many unknowns to this. President Trump's applying pressure if he sees the economy slipping away. China getting destabilized by low growth if they don't get control of the Corona Virus. Public unrest in China if people feel less legitimacy toward the ability of the Communist Party to be proficient. Global supply chains disrupted by China's internal problems. Downturn in sales to China due to the virus's continuing or after-effects. The problem with the Trump era, in general, is that there is no stabilizing force to calm the world's concerns because the US is longer seen as a predictable actor to guide international reactions. Often, even countries that did agree with the US still liked the US as a pillar of norms in dangerous times. After all it was largely the Us that created the current ground rules of international behavior.

Market conditions and the current threat of Pandemics are going to slow down some of the major economies.  Threat to supply chains may temper world markets leading to global slowdown, Fed will likely hold the line or go higher.
Market and economy is hot right now. I think the fed wants to keep it the same going into the elections but won’t be able to do so. Better to do rate increase sooner than closer to elections.

Due to it being an election year and the uncertain impact of 2019-nCoV on the economy, the Fed won't raise rates unexpectedly. Whether they keep it the same or raise it depends on how 2019-nCoV effects the economy, which may not be fully understood until after April. They may lower it to help companies that need to re orientate their supply chains due to factory closures in China that currently have no set endpoint.
As the economy cools there will be pressure to lower the rate.  Trump is already talking it down and his reelection depends on a strong stock market.

Current trends in aggregate financial conditions suggest no immediate need to be more accommodative; at least not when pertaining to the Federal Funds rate.  Corona Virus will likely impact major Asian trading partners but this flow-through will likely impact the US economy in a small way.
No change in an election year.  By June the world will only then have understanding of impact corona virus has had on China's citizens and GDP.
Because with a look on corona and the effects it will have on economy the next months fed will do nothing unexpected that could unsettle someone. Its the safe solution

Absent Coronavirus, there would be no obvious reason to change given the Fed’s logic of the last year. The economic damage to global supply chains won’t be clear until the epidemic peaks. The timing of the peak is totally unclear at this point.

The Federal Reserve left the target range for its federal funds rate unchanged at 1.5-1.75 percent on January 29th 2020 as expected, saying the current stance of monetary policy is appropriate to support sustained expansion of economic activity, strong labor market conditions, and inflation returning to the 2 percent objective. The first monetary policy decision from the Fed in 2020 suggests that no changes in the funds rate should be expected during this year, in line with FOMC projections made in December.
Almost always required to raise the limits
I believe the economy will stagnate in '20, necessitating lower interest rates.
Fed is not going to raise rates in election year.

I really think it depends on how everything with the economy shakes out in the next month or so on the heels of the Coronavirus.  I think we are heading for increased unemployment in the next few months which will lead to less consumer spending and less consumer confidence.  If it is significantly less, inflation should trend downward.  If not It should stay the same.  My only reasoning for any percentage in the "higher" region is if something significant were to happen which would lead to Congress passing some kind of economic relief or bailout adding an influx of cash into the market causing inflation.

The improvement in the US manufacturing data should strengthen the fundamentals in the US but not enough to move the range as the fed will want to see at least a few quarters of sustainable performance.  By the time these meetings happening, they will need to have seen such a high level of strength in the underlying data (including inflation data) that its just unlikely to see that level of strength in the time period we're forecasting. The length of intensity of the corona virus will be a headwind but given where the case rates are in the US, feels like the improvement in data offsets any drag from the virus.

The strong economy, recent polling showing an improved approval rate for Trump, and his acquittal will stabilize the decision process for the FED for the rest of the year.  Only a sudden incident (Coronavirus, terrorist attack, major political meltdown) will move the needle

Oil prices are falling due to virus in China, and inventories have greatly increase.  Falling oil prices should greatly reduce inflationary pressure.  The economy of the US is also slowing to a GDP of just over 2.1 for the last quarter of 2019.  This is also deflationary.

The Fed has been more cautious in raising rates during an election year (even if the Fed chair says it does not influence their decision).  The safest choice is to keep things neutral unless something big happens that pushes the FED to lower rates (i.e. the Coronavirus spreads outside of China).  
Except for some unknown global situation or major change in the market outlook, there would not be any change in the rates for the rest of the year.
https://www.marketplace.org/2020/01/09/the-fed-says-the-economy-is-in-a-good-place-could-it-be-doing-more/
if one looks at leading indicators for the US economy in combination with global headwinds (corona virus) there is a decent chance the Fed will ease again in a couple of months form now.

The Fed is currently in a wait and see mode, saying that it will take some major development to make it change its current fed funds rate. Inflation has been disappointing given the stage of the business cycle, so a rate cut could be performed to try to boost it closer to the Fed's target of 2 %. If a cut were to take place at the March or April meeting of the FOMC, it's unlikely it would be followed by a second cut in June.
Coronavirus may result in economic slowdown, possibly necessitating a lower rate.

I think the Fed wants to stay as far away as they can from being viewed as tilting politically.  The economy may be slowing down a bit, in which case there is some low probability they lower rates.  Lowering rates won't annoy the President.  Inevitably his behavior will influence the Fed to some degree, so raising rates would be very unlikely given the tweetstorm that would arise.

At close of business on 10 June 2020, will the upper limit of the Federal Reserve's target range for the federal funds rate be lower, the same, or higher than it was at close of business on 29 April 2020?
Look Ma, no hands. Anything the Fed would do in this timeframe would be construed as politically motivated. There may be other less obvious levers that can help keep the engine rolling thru the virus stall.
